Define Documentation

#define CPPoffsetof (  type,
field   )     (reinterpret_cast<long>(&((reinterpret_cast<type*>(0))->*(&type::field))))
 

Replacement for C's offsetof macro. In theory, C's offsetof() doesn't work with non-POD (non-"Plain Old Data" - that is, a class or struct with only data and which doesn't override the "&" operator). So, a good C++ compiler will complain about our use of offsetof below. The following macro ought to work instead, although it depends on the length of an ordinary pointer being the same length as a "long" (it's easy to change: reinterpret_cast<long>).

You can understand this better by the following stages:
Type *nullTypePtr = 0; // reinterpret_cast<Type*>(0)
int Type::*offset = &Type::field;
long offset = reinterpret_cast<int>(&(nullTypePtr->*field));

#define SAFE_STRCPY (  dest,
src   )     { strncpy(dest, src, sizeof (dest)); dest[sizeof (dest) - 1] = '\0'; }
 

Safe version of strcpy(). It checks the length and only works for things like "char Xyz[100]"; it won't work for dynamically allocated (e.g., "char *Xyz = malloc(100)") or function parameters ... and it won't give an error message that it isn't working (although the bad results should be immediately obvious)

Parameters:
dest The destination of the copy (must not be dynamically allocated or a function pointer).
src The source of the copy.

#define SMEAR (  dest,
fill   )     { memset(dest, fill, sizeof (dest)); }
 

Fill a C-string with all the same value, to make Purify happy. Only works for things like "char Xyz[100]"; it wo't work for dynamically allocated (e.g., "char *Xyz = malloc(100)") or function parameters ... and it won't give an error message that it isn't working (although the bad results should be immediately obvious)

Parameters:
dest The destination to be smeared (must not be dynamically allocated or a function pointer).
fill The fill character.

Enumeration Type Documentation

anonymous enum
 

yuck: a global ... defined in IPDRsim.cpp

An enumeration of all the template key IDs. Note that there is a unique number of each key, regardless of which template it is used in. The weird number scheme is for historical reasons: some fields were added later.

Enumeration values:

00115 {
00116     for (int i = 0; i < numKeys; i++) {
00117         ostr << keys[i].KeyID << ":\t";
00118         switch (keys[i].KeyTypeID) {
00119         case XDR_TYPE_BOOLEAN:  ostr << "bool    "; break;
00120         case XDR_TYPE_UBYTE:    ostr << "uint8   "; break;
00121         case XDR_TYPE_BYTE:     ostr << "int8    "; break;
00122         case XDR_TYPE_USHORT:   ostr << "uint16  "; break;
00123         case XDR_TYPE_SHORT:    ostr << "int16   "; break;

00125         case XDR_TYPE_INT:      ostr << "int32   "; break;
00126         case XDR_TYPE_ULONG:    ostr << "uint64  "; break;
00127         case XDR_TYPE_LONG:     ostr << "int64   "; break;
00128         case XDR_TYPE_FLOAT:    ostr << "float   "; break;
00129         case XDR_TYPE_DOUBLE:   ostr << "double  "; break;
00130         case XDR_TYPE_STRING:   ostr << "string  "; break;
00131                 /*XDR_TYPE_HEXBINARY bug in specs HEXBINARY and BASE64 have same type ID*/
00132                 case XDR_TYPE_BASE64:   ostr << "base64 | hexbinary"; break;
00133         case XDR_TYPE_IPV4ADDR: ostr << "ipv4Addr"; break;
00134         case XDR_TYPE_IPV6ADDR: ostr << "ipv6Addr"; break;
00135         case XDR_TYPE_DATETIME: ostr << "dateTime ";break;
00136         case XDR_TYPE_TIMEMSEC: ostr << "timeMsec"; break;
00137         case XDR_TYPE_TIMEUSEC: ostr << "timeUsec"; break;
00138         default: ostr << "type#" << keys[i].KeyTypeID;  break;
00139         }
00140         ostr << " " << keys[i].KeyName << "\t";
00141         switch (keys[i].AccessType) {
00142         case IPDR_ACCESS_BY_OFFSET:
00143         {
00144             ostr << "offset " << reinterpret_cast<IPDR_Offset>(keys[i].KeyAccessor);
00145         }
00146         break;
00147         case IPDR_ACCESS_BY_FUNCTION:
00148             ostr << "function " << keys[i].KeyAccessor << "(" << keys[i].ExtraData << ")";
00149             break;
00150         default:
00151             ostr << "unknown access<#" << keys[i].AccessType << ">";
00152         }
00153         ostr << endl;
00154     }
00155     return ostr << "\t(" << numKeys << " keys)" << endl;
00156 }

static char* timestampStr (  char *  buf,
size_t  bufSize,
IPDR_Time  timestamp
)  [static]
 

Create a time-stamp string to something like ISO standard form

Parameters:
buf (updated) Buffer for the string
bufSize Size of buf
timestamp The time value to turn into a string
Returns:
C-string with the timestamp, a pointer into buf 
00195 {
00196     struct tm tmMem;
00197     struct tm* tmPtr = localtime_r(&timestamp, &tmMem);
00198     strftime(buf, bufSize, "%Y-%m-%d %H:%M:%S", tmPtr);
00199     return buf;
00200 }

Variable Documentation

bool fastFillFlag
 

A global flag for whether we're trying to fill the output records fast (all the same) or slowly (more variation in the fields).
